title: Response To Comments: The Tax Bill Is Still Very Bad
summary:
Key ideas
- Mick Mulvaney said the richest 20% pay 84-95% of income taxes, while the poorest 80% pay between 90-280 billion.
- Halving income taxes for the bottom 80% of the population could be a cost-neutral alternative for the GOP bill.
- CEOs are unlikely to invest the tax cut in cool economic-growth boosting stuff that will spur the economy, according to the Forbes.
- The proposed tax bill may not benefit poor and middle-class people, but incentivizes CEOs and stakeholders and costs the government money.
- Giving poor and middle-class people more money is a more direct and more effective way to help them than spending the money on complicated government programs or corporate tax cuts.

Key learnings
- The proposed tax bill is not an effective way to uplift poor and middle-class people's lives.
- Giving more money to poor and middle-class people is a more direct, effective, and cost-efficient alternative.
- The current tax bill incentivizes corporations and stakeholders.

Key questions 
- Is there any reason to prefer the GOP plan to halve income taxes for the bottom 80% of the population?
- Will the tax bill turbo-charge the economy and positively impact poor and middle-class people?
- Should the government spend the tax money on social welfare programs, expanding EITC, or cutting personal income taxes in lower brackets instead of the current proposal?
